awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Side-channel Attacks Against Mobile Users: Singularity Detection, Behavior Identification, and Automated Rectification
awd_abstract_narration:
Side-channel attacks have been proven effective to infer sensitive information (such as user activities) that should not be disclosed to unauthorized users. Owing to the closed nature of the cellular network infrastructure, adversaries cannot easily capture encrypted mobile network traffic, thus protecting against side-channel information leakage of mobile users. However, with the recent proliferation of software defined radio platforms and emerging Internet Protocol-based cellular network services over public networks (including Wi-Fi calling), mobile phone users are now exposed to more serious side-channel information leakage than before. This project aims to conduct a comprehensive investigation of side-channel attacks against mobile phone users by collecting, labeling, mining, and analyzing mobile users' encrypted mobile data. The success of this research will not only contribute new techniques to discover security vulnerabilities that can be exploited from side-channel information leakage, but also develop novel automated rectification mechanisms to safeguard users. The proposed activities may contribute to the upcoming 5G technology standardization and train a new generation of engineers and students. 

This project makes three technical contributions: (1) New techniques for mobile data collection and labeling: Cellular network control-plane signals indicate a variety of cellular network events (such as changes in a user's Quality-of-Service profile or location) which may be exploited to invade user privacy. However, the current-generation cellular sniffers cannot distinguish well between control-plane signals and data-plane data packets when they are transmitted over the same physical channel. This project will develop new techniques to collect encrypted mobile network traffic including control-plane signals and data-plane data packets and label them with user behaviors and network events; (2) Advanced Singularity Detection and Behavior Identification mechanism: This project will study and develop end-to-end frameworks that can perform singularity detection and behavior identification simultaneously. This involves processing limited labeled data and mining frequent patterns for emerging behaviors; (3) Mobile/cellular-friendly automated rectification mechanisms: The state-of-the-art security defenses for side-channel attacks are not designed for mobile networked systems. For example, mobile users pay a performance penalty for the noise added to their data packets. This project will develop mobile-friendly (meaning low memory usage) and cellular-friendly (meaning compatible with standards and operators' charging model) automated rectification mechanisms to secure a variety of mobile devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The cellular network is a large-scale, global infrastructure comparable to the Internet. All control-plane signalings and data-plane traffic between mobile devices and the infrastructure are transmitted over secure radio connections, ensuring that all data is encrypted. Due to the closeness of the operational cellular network infrastructure, adversaries cannot easily intercept users' encrypted mobile network traffic transmitted over the air. Therefore, mobile users have been immune to serious side-channel attacks for the last decade. However, with the proliferation of commercial cellular network sniffing platforms, mobile users are no longer immune to side-channel information leakage, as adversaries can capture the aforementioned encrypted mobile network traffic, though they may not easily distinguish control-plane signalings from data-plane traffic. Thus, the objective of this project was to rigorously explore possible side-channel attacks against mobile users and develop automated rectification mechanisms to safeguard users.

The outcomes of this project are classified into intellectual merit and broader impacts as follows:

Intellectual Merit:  This project has pushed current side-channel attacks against mobile users to a new frontier through a series of research results. First, we developed an open-sourced 4G LTE sniffer supporting both uplink and downlink sniffing functionalities, providing the research community with a low-cost platform facilitating side-channel attack studies in mobile ecosystem. Second, we created a dataset that collected cellular network traces during users' access to 92 of the top 100 popular Internet applications, such as Walmart, Microsoft Teams, Netflix, and Lyft, labeled with user activities. This dataset facilitates the application of various machine learning techniques to discover data singularities (features) from encrypted mobile network signalings and traffic. Third, we investigated essential mobile services, including 5G/4G voice and text services, pre-installed by carriers on all mobile phones, uncovering vulnerabilities that unintentionally leak 5G/4G call state information despite encryption protection. These vulnerabilities arise from recent call optimization techniques standardized in 3GPP specifications and adopted by mobile network operators. While effective in enhancing 5G/4G call quality and efficiency, these optimization techniques expose additional call information that can be exploited to precisely infer call states and launch side-channel attacks. Specifically, the study shows that by exploiting inferred call states, adversaries can discern the caller and the recipient (in the case of robocalls) and launch corresponding attacks (e.g., voice DoS) against high-value victims. Fourth, we designed a standard-compliant PDCP-layer-based solution to efficiently remove all singularities embedded in users’ mobile traffic without incurring additional monetary costs, thereby defending against various side-channel attacks.

Broader Impacts: This research made real-world impacts in the following ways. First, the project advanced the security analysis of side-channel attacks against mobile users. Second, the development of a free, open-source 4G LTE sniffer platform for eavesdropping on mobile users' communications, along with the labeled dataset covering 92 of the top 100 popular mobile applications, can facilitate and inspire further studies on side-channel attacks. Third, educational resources, including course materials on mobile networks, have been created as part of this project. Lastly, the research results have been published in prestigious security and networking venues such as IEEE CNS, ACM MobiCom, and IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2023
Modified by: Guan-Hua Tu

Broader Impacts: This research made real-world impacts in the following ways. First, the project advanced the security analysis of side-channel attacks against mobile users.
